Bug.Summery: Open package explorer warm tests: hard to measure since they are fast

Lines.Line: - run the test in a loop for 10 times
- assert that opening the package explorer in a warm test takes less than
500ms. From a user expierence it doesn't really matter if something takes 100
or 200 ms.

Bug.WithStack:
Tobias, the open package explorer warm tests only take a short period of time < 100ms. Those tests are candidates for false positive failures since they are highly valunerable to little changes. I opt that we change this as follows:
- run the test in a loop for 10 times - assert that opening the package explorer in a warm test takes less than 500ms. From a user expierence it doesn't really matter if something takes 100 or 200 ms.
I have made the changes in HEAD. If you agree, can you please backport them to 2.1.3 & 3.0.x We do not show this test anymore
Bug.WithOutStack:
Tobias, the open package explorer warm tests only take a short period of time < 100ms. Those tests are candidates for false positive failures since they are highly valunerable to little changes. I opt that we change this as follows:

I have made the changes in HEAD. If you agree, can you please backport them to 2.1.3 & 3.0.x We do not show this test anymore

Bug.Summery: classloading problem
Bug.WithStack:
I wanted to switch from the Java Perspective to the Synchronize Perspective and got an error that the view could not be instantiated. This is from the logs. It seems that the classloader is somehow messed up. The only thing I did up to that was start an Ant task that starts up Tomcat in a new VM, then perform a global search and replace in some ASP files.

Bug.Summery: CommonBaseEventLogRecrod produces invalid Common Base Events.

Lines.Line: 1) When the user sets a message, we make the assumption that it is not
localized and set it as the CBE's msg. When the resource bundle name is set,
we move the CBE's msg to the CBE's msgDataElement.msgCatalogId. Of course,
this would have to be done if the reverse order was used to call the setters.
The disadvantage of this solution is that the user would have to know if the
message was either localized or not to resolve the message but this is not a
far stretch since consumers typically need to know this information to resolve
msgDataElements.
2) Set a dummy value for the CBE's msgDataElement.msgCatalog until the user
sets the resource bundle name.
Localization could be done in either case by first checking for a Common Base
Event's msg with corresponding Message Data Element's msgLocale, then falling
back to the Message Data Element if the msg is not present or locale is not the
one desired.
Created attachment 22027
Proposed fix.
CommonBaseEventLogRecord and JUnit test cases checked-in to TPTP 4.0 (HEAD) on
June 6, 2005. Here is a summary of the fix and its assumptions:

Bug.WithStack:
CommonBaseEventLogRecrod produces invalid Common Base Events.
If one calls the setMessage method, it sets the message into the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.MsgCatalogId. The problem is that if there is no subsequent call to setResourceBundleName, then the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.MsgCatalog and CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.MsgCatalogType values don't get set, and a call to CommonBaseEvent.validate() will flag an error (since it wants MsgCatalogId, MsgCatalog, and MsgCatalogType to be all there when any are set).
The problem is that with JSR47, the message can either be localizable, or not localizable, whereas with CBE, if you start to fill in the MsgCatalog info, you have to finish it.
The net effect is that someone using CBELogRecord could correctly call setMessage without setResourceBundleName which would result in an invalid CBE.
here are couple of solutions for this problem:
1) When the user sets a message, we make the assumption that it is not localized and set it as the CBE's msg. When the resource bundle name is set, we move the CBE's msg to the CBE's msgDataElement.msgCatalogId. Of course, this would have to be done if the reverse order was used to call the setters. The disadvantage of this solution is that the user would have to know if the message was either localized or not to resolve the message but this is not a far stretch since consumers typically need to know this information to resolve msgDataElements.
2) Set a dummy value for the CBE's msgDataElement.msgCatalog until the user sets the resource bundle name. Localization could be done in either case by first checking for a Common Base Event's msg with corresponding Message Data Element's msgLocale, then falling back to the Message Data Element if the msg is not present or locale is not the one desired. Created attachment 22027 Proposed fix. CommonBaseEventLogRecord and JUnit test cases checked-in to TPTP 4.0 (HEAD) on June 6, 2005. Here is a summary of the fix and its assumptions:
-When a CommonBaseEventLogRecord is first created, the parameter CommonBaseEvent is assummed to be valid (e.g. resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) messages in the CommonBaseEvent.msg property and unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) messages in the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property).
-When the CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setMessage(String) method is called, the parameter message is assummed to be resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) and set to the CommonBaseEvent.msg property. However, if a resource bundle name has been previously set (e.g. by calling CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundleName(String) or setting the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalog property in the parameter CommonBaseEvent), the parameter message is assummed to be unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) and set to the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property.
-When the CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundleName(String) method is called, the resource bundle name is set as previously mapped. However, if the parameter resource bundle name is not null, the message is assummed to be unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) and if a non-null message is set on the CommonBaseEvent.msg property, it is moved to the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property and if the parameter resource bundle name is null, the message is assummed to be resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) and if a non-null message is set on the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property, it is moved to the CommonBaseEvent.msg property.
-When the CommonBaseEventLogRecord.getMessage() method is called, the message is assummed to be resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) and returned from the CommonBaseEvent.msg property. However, if a resource bundle name has been previously set (e.g. by calling CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundleName (String) or setting the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalog property in the parameter CommonBaseEvent), the message is assummed to be unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) and returned from the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property.
-The CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundle(ResourceBundle) and CommonBaseEventLogRecord.getResourceBundle() methods delegate to the superclass (e.g. LogRecord).
Verified in Toronto's TPTP 200506101909 (HEAD) build on June 13, 2005. Closing.
Bug.WithOutStack:
CommonBaseEventLogRecrod produces invalid Common Base Events.
If one calls the setMessage method, it sets the message into the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.MsgCatalogId. The problem is that if there is no subsequent call to setResourceBundleName, then the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.MsgCatalog and CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.MsgCatalogType values don't get set, and a call to CommonBaseEvent.validate() will flag an error (since it wants MsgCatalogId, MsgCatalog, and MsgCatalogType to be all there when any are set).
The problem is that with JSR47, the message can either be localizable, or not localizable, whereas with CBE, if you start to fill in the MsgCatalog info, you have to finish it.
The net effect is that someone using CBELogRecord could correctly call setMessage without setResourceBundleName which would result in an invalid CBE.
here are couple of solutions for this problem:
1) When the user sets a message, we make the assumption that it is not localized and set it as the CBE's msg. When the resource bundle name is set, we move the CBE's msg to the CBE's msgDataElement.msgCatalogId. Of course, this would have to be done if the reverse order was used to call the setters. The disadvantage of this solution is that the user would have to know if the message was either localized or not to resolve the message but this is not a far stretch since consumers typically need to know this information to resolve msgDataElements.
2) Set a dummy value for the CBE's msgDataElement.msgCatalog until the user sets the resource bundle name. Localization could be done in either case by first checking for a Common Base Event's msg with corresponding Message Data Element's msgLocale, then falling back to the Message Data Element if the msg is not present or locale is not the one desired. Created attachment 22027 Proposed fix. CommonBaseEventLogRecord and JUnit test cases checked-in to TPTP 4.0 (HEAD) on June 6, 2005. Here is a summary of the fix and its assumptions:
-When a CommonBaseEventLogRecord is first created, the parameter CommonBaseEvent is assummed to be valid (e.g. resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) messages in the CommonBaseEvent.msg property and unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) messages in the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property).
-When the CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setMessage(String) method is called, the parameter message is assummed to be resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) and set to the CommonBaseEvent.msg property. However, if a resource bundle name has been previously set (e.g. by calling CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundleName(String) or setting the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalog property in the parameter CommonBaseEvent), the parameter message is assummed to be unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) and set to the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property.
-When the CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundleName(String) method is called, the resource bundle name is set as previously mapped. However, if the parameter resource bundle name is not null, the message is assummed to be unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) and if a non-null message is set on the CommonBaseEvent.msg property, it is moved to the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property and if the parameter resource bundle name is null, the message is assummed to be resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) and if a non-null message is set on the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property, it is moved to the CommonBaseEvent.msg property.
-When the CommonBaseEventLogRecord.getMessage() method is called, the message is assummed to be resolved (e.g. localized and formatted) and returned from the CommonBaseEvent.msg property. However, if a resource bundle name has been previously set (e.g. by calling CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundleName (String) or setting the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalog property in the parameter CommonBaseEvent), the message is assummed to be unresolved (e.g. unlocalized and unformatted) and returned from the CommonBaseEvent.MsgDataElement.msgCatalogId property.
-The CommonBaseEventLogRecord.setResourceBundle(ResourceBundle) and CommonBaseEventLogRecord.getResourceBundle() methods delegate to the superclass (e.g. LogRecord).
Verified in Toronto's TPTP 200506101909 (HEAD) build on June 13, 2005. Closing.

[content assist] context info popup stack not cleaned up correctly
Bug.WithStack:
Using the content assist (SourceViewer inside a view/CellEditor, not editor) gives some dubious behaviour while dealing with the context info popups: If I leave the text control by TAB there might be more than one ContextFrame instance on the fContextFrameStack for whatever reason (class org.eclipse.jface.text.contentassist.ContextInformationPopup, line 433ff). The problem is that only the last one is pop()ed from the stack, resulting in the previous one showing up again. I think traversing out of the control to which the content assist is connected should always hide *all* remaining context info popups - by now I can only think of an IContextInformationValidator that looks wheter the TextViewer is no longer the focus control. Or am I missing something? Build id?

Bug.Summery: Model persistence fails for inner aspects of inner classes (and others)
Bug.WithStack: If you install the attached test project, build it and then switch off build automatically you will notice that when you restart the workbench you will not get the "Advises" and "Advised By" menus when you right click on the gutter markers, which is one of the ways to test that persistence has worked. I also had ClassCastExceptions in the error log. I believe there will also be related cases that fail because you can have any depth of nested inner classes and aspects. This is because the model does not persist information about inner classes or aspects more than one level deep. Created attachment 20827 Test project Fixed in RC1
Bug.WithOutStack: If you install the attached test project, build it and then switch off build automatically you will notice that when you restart the workbench you will not get the "Advises" and "Advised By" menus when you right click on the gutter markers, which is one of the ways to test that persistence has worked. I also had ClassCastExceptions in the error log. I believe there will also be related cases that fail because you can have any depth of nested inner classes and aspects. This is because the model does not persist information about inner classes or aspects more than one level deep. Created attachment 20827 Test project Fixed in RC1

Bug.Summery: can't compile pde.core
Bug.WithStack:
N20050509-0010 If you fetch pde.core, pde.ui and pde build from HEAD. You will notice that pde.core does not compile because it can not find runtime.
If you try to update the classpath, you will notice that pde.core name does not appear in the dialog.
Note that if instead you use the last I build, everything works fine. If this one happens again, close and reopen the project.
I was not able to reproduce on any build. I suspect this has to do with the timing of resource notifications, as files are being checked out from cvs, which is unpredictable.
Will keep an eye on it, as such a bug is very disconcerting. Fixed. I was able to reproduce it with the org.eclipse.ui.workbench plugin.
This was a corner case (ie. the order/timing of things getting checked out) that was surfaced after the fix for bug 93818.

Bug.Summery: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when gathering data via Agent Controller

source_code.code: /** Recursively process a buffer of raw data. */
/* Did we get the entire header, if not return */

Lines.Line: 1. Use https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22606 DLL with a recent
AgentController (in AgentController\bin folder)
2. Run the workbench with the following debug flags enabled see
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22607 and
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22608
3. from this instance profile the workbench to a file with just execution
details: see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22609 for options
and a filter that has one line which includes everything (* * include).

Bug.WithStack:
During long runs we often experience the following exception which causes the stream to die (so no more data is sent back to the loaders):
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 10301 at org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.local.common.TCPDataServer$BufferFlusher.p rocessData(TCPDataServer.java:341) at org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.local.common.TCPDataServer$BufferFlusher.r un(TCPDataServer.java:411)
Monitoring large numbers of statistical agent counters (e.g. Perfmon) for an extended period of time can reproduce this problem. Please investigate the root cause in org.eclipse.hyades.execution plugin. The fix should be applied to both plugings org.eclipse.hyades.execution and org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.
The problem here seems to be a boundary case.
In the processData method if all the calls which pass the array pass a clone then the problem seems to go away:
e.g.
inside the call
... /** Recursively process a buffer of raw data. */ protected int processData(byte[] data, int offset, int limit, InetAddress addr) ...
pass in a cloned array to
... return processData((byte[])data.clone(), offset+1, limit, addr); ...
and
... _processor.incommingData((byte[])_binaryForwardBuffer.clone(), _bytesWritten, addr); ...
(in all cases)
It would appear that the problem is occuring as a result of the array being modified inside either a recursive method call or another method call. I think the problem is occuring because of the modification of the array during recursion (possibly as a result of array reallocation?) Mike and I have been looking at this bug further to try and get a solution sometime soon.
The purpose of the processData method in the BufferFlusher is to parse a fixed size buffer byte array for messages (of variable length) and to forward these messages onto the data processor. It is possible for message headers to be contained anywhere within the buffer arrays. We believe that the exception is getting thrown when the message header is contained at the end of the buffer in its entirity.
The length of the _binaryForwardBuffer is set once the entire message header has been read. This is correct behaviour, as you cannot parse an incomplete header to determine its length. The condition
/* Is this a new message? */ if(_currentHeaderOffset<MESSAGE_HEADER_LENGTH)
is true if we have not read the entire message header. In this case we attempt to read the header from the byte array buffer, starting from the current index position.
current=this.loadMessageHeader(data, current, limit);
We then must return if we do not get the entire header
/* Did we get the entire header, if not return */ if(current==limit) { return current; }
..... proceed to set binaryForwardBuffer size now...
The condition current==limit is incorrect, and will be true if the entire header has been read at the end of the buffer. This will result in the binaryForwardBuffer size not being reset correctly. If the new message is of a larger length to the previous then we will exceed the binaryForwardBuffer length (as this has not been sent).
We think the problem is related to this, and that the "current==limit" condition should be replaced with "_currentHeaderOffset < MESSAGE_HEADER_LENGTH". Another inefficiency we have noted - the byte forward array is always getting reallocated for buffers of length > MAX_MESSAGE_LENGTH.
The condition if(getMessageLength() >= _currentBufferSize) { // Reallocate in here // Copy array contents in here }
seems bizarre. Surely the byte array should only be resized if it is not long enough already? George thanks a lot for your help. I'm looking into refactoring that code and also I will try to streamline the whole interaction (Agent Controler client -> Workbench), I hope to fix the Crimson parser also through this operation. Antony if you use Zone Labs please could you confirm that this problem disappears if the firewall is off ?
I've added some recovery mechanism althoug as I mention bellow it might fail in some cases.
If you want to try the old TCPDataServer code set org.eclipse.hyades.execution/debug/useOldDataServer = true
Details about the findings: --------------------------- In the past few weeks I tried to figure out what could cause the problem described in this bug report.
I rewrote the workbench side of agent controller data channel client and also I simplified the whole data flow from socket listener to model loaders to be sure that the problem is not there, but the problem was still happening.
Yesterday I finally realized what caused it and this will affect all the components that uses the agent controller data channel (also the command channel could be affected).
The firewall is the culprit (I have this problem with Zone Labs firewall although it might happen also with other firewalls).
I have Zone Labs Integrity Client 3.5 up all the time and all the other applications seems to work fine.
On my hyper-threading machine I had visible problems only in Eclipse the debugger and also our data communication layer were affected.
I always though that this is a hyper-threading problem because on my other (single-threading single-cpu machine) I haven't seen such problems (I couldn't even reproduce the defect). The problem seems to be amplified on hyper-threading machines where can be reproduced in some situations (on long runs, when lots of data is transferred).
Yesterday I tried to FTP a large file to my hyper-threading machine and I always got a corrupted one with no errors and this problem made me think about the firewall, then I asked Robert Danek to build an agent controller that will dump the data to a file before it sends it over the wire (this should become a debug option on the agent controller) so I could compare what was send with what was received so I found that some messages were truncated during transfer.
Today I ran several tests with the firewall on and always received truncated messages, then I disabled the firewall and tried again with the old code and my new implementation and both worked fine - the problem disappeared.
In most situations we cannot recover gracefully so we probably need to add a readme entry about this behavior and also when we debug code which uses the communication layer make sure we are not affected by this behavior when Zone Labs firewall is on.
The machine(s) we have used to reproduce this bug don't have Zone Labs firewall and the main machine we used to reproduce the problem regularly didn't have any firewall at all. It also wasn't hyperthreaded. Given that we don't use a firewall and in particular we don't use Zone Labs, this couldn't be the source of our problem. Antony although you don't use a firewall or a hyper-threading machine I still think you receive bad messages (that's the root cause of the problem). I sent you by e-mail a test scenario, please run it and let me know how it goes. Created attachment 22606 Modified DLL to log messages in a file before they are sent of the wire Created attachment 22607 Debug flags for the execution plugin Created attachment 22608 Debug flags for the models plugin Created attachment 22609 Execution time analysis options I post the scenario here also:
1. Use https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22606 DLL with a recent AgentController (in AgentController\bin folder) 2. Run the workbench with the following debug flags enabled see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22607 and https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22608 3. from this instance profile the workbench to a file with just execution details: see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=22609 for options and a filter that has one line which includes everything (* * include).
You can also run you scenario, but the profile scenario might get you there faster.
You should get several log files, one in the AgentController bin folder and another two in the \ folder of the disk drive where you started the runtime workbench (not the development one).
At some point you should see some errors on the console and then if you compare the AgentController \bin log with \messageValue... log you should see some missing data in the second one.
Please let me know if you see this problem there. Please test with the latest code from CVS it should fix the problem. It seems that lot's of time out error were triggered by the firewall and somehow we didn't handle correctly those cases.
Also the time out probably happend on your scenario because you might send events at a rate less then 1 per second which is the timeout seting on our communication socket. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: [content assist][5.0] Code completion gives illegal static import
Bug.WithStack:
Code completion allows a package and class to be chosen for a static import declaration, which is good. The problem is that as soon as the user chooses the class, the static import is completed with a semicolon immediately following the class name, and this is illegal. Instead code completion should follow the choosing of the class with a choice for static members (and asterisk). Don't know if this is text of JDT/Core. We should address this for 3.1. we receive the proposal as is from core. already there.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 94303 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Code completion allows a package and class to be chosen for a static import declaration, which is good. The problem is that as soon as the user chooses the class, the static import is completed with a semicolon immediately following the class name, and this is illegal. Instead code completion should follow the choosing of the class with a choice for static members (and asterisk). Don't know if this is text of JDT/Core. We should address this for 3.1. we receive the proposal as is from core. already there.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 94303 ***

Bug.Summery: Missing occurrence from task text
Bug.WithStack:
On the latest Ant occurrence code, setting the cursor in the property reference in the echo text will mark the target name occurrences. This will work fine if properties and targets do not have the same names.
<project name="project" default="default">
<target name="default" depends="test" description="--> description"> <property name="test" value="yo"/> </target>
<target name="test"> <echo>${test}</echo> </target>
</project> Deferred to post 3.1 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
On the latest Ant occurrence code, setting the cursor in the property reference in the echo text will mark the target name occurrences. This will work fine if properties and targets do not have the same names.
<project name="project" default="default">
<target name="default" depends="test" description="--> description"> <property name="test" value="yo"/> </target>
<target name="test"> <echo>${test}</echo> </target>
</project> Deferred to post 3.1 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: DBCS3.1: Error stacks when operating TCP/IP monitor

Lines.Line: 1. open TCP/IP monitor at context menu at Server view
2. operate start, stop, edit, or add TCP/IP monitor
1. start up Tomcat 5.0
2. Select Monitoring > Monitor port 8080 (HTTP) at the server's context menu
3. open Monitor Ports at Monitoring > Properties... at the context menu
4. click Stop for HTTP 8080, then click OK to close
5. open Window > Preferences... Internet > TCP/IP Monitor
6. Click Start for localhost:8080 HTTP, then OK to close
7. open Monitoring > Properties... at the server's context menu
Here is a problem ; Status for HTTP is displayed as "Stopped"
8. click Edit.. for the HTTP
got follwoing error stack

Bug.Summery: RFE: Refactoring that generates a static import.
Bug.WithStack: A handy refactoring would be to take a qualified reference of a static member and convert it into an unqualified reference supported by a static import declaration. So JOptionPane.OK_OPTION could be refactored to OK_OPTION, with a static import declaration added if needed. Add Import (Ctrl+Shift+M) is your friend.
Bug.WithOutStack: A handy refactoring would be to take a qualified reference of a static member and convert it into an unqualified reference supported by a static import declaration. So JOptionPane.OK_OPTION could be refactored to OK_OPTION, with a static import declaration added if needed. Add Import (Ctrl+Shift+M) is your friend.

Bug.Summery: Clarification for translation
Bug.WithStack:
Opened on behalf of the Chinese translator:
Hello,
For file: hyades.runtime_3.0\plugins\org.eclipse.hyades.statistical.ui_3.3.0\plugin.properties
Does "file drop" mean "file block"? or, pls explain it with more detailed text.
Thanks in advance!
Best Regards Steven Hou "file drop" refers to drag and drop - e.g. the user dragging a file from one window to another window. The error such as "Invalid file drop" is merely saying that the drag and drop operation the user has attempted is not valid. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this originator of this enhancement/defect has an inactive Bugzilla account and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: [Workbench] Performance test regression caused by workbench harness change

Lines.Line: - Remove the three second delay
- Add a system property to avoid blocking on early startup participants before
running the tests. This would be used by any performance test that is sensitive
to startup time.
If we add the system property, it seems like we could keep the delay in for the
UI tests. Do you see any reason not to?

Bug.WithStack:
N20050509
Core has a UI startup test that measures the time until UITestApplication starts running. This test had a 16% improvement over 3.0 in 3.1 M6, and since late last week has a 33% regression. This appears to be caused by a change in Workbench that now waits until early startup participants complete, combined with the new early startup participant in the ui test plugin that waits for three seconds.
Discussing with Nick, the plan is to: - Remove the three second delay - Add a system property to avoid blocking on early startup participants before running the tests. This would be used by any performance test that is sensitive to startup time. If we add the system property, it seems like we could keep the delay in for the UI tests. Do you see any reason not to?
Added the system property check to WorkbenchTestable.
To disable waiting for early startup, specify the system property: org.eclipse.ui.testWaitForEarlyStartup=false
E.g. add the VM arg: -Dorg.eclipse.ui.testWaitForEarlyStartup=false
The three second delay won't affect the performance tests once I add the system property. The only concern is how this impacts the total time required to run the SDK tests. It won't affect 99% of core tests that run a different application, so it's hard for me to judge. You could maybe chop it down to 1 second. I have made the change to the UI performance startup test for the next integration build. I have made the change to the UI performance startup test for the next integration build. Looks like leaving in the delay is not a problem. Closing.
What you released does not match comment #2. The property being tested in HEAD is:
org.eclipse.ui.testsWaitForEarlyStartup
Note the extra "s" (testsWait instead of testWait...). Therefore the performance test still failed in N20050512-0010
Do you want to fix the typo or should I just change my reference in the performance test? Sorry about that. If you could update the tests, I'd prefer to leave the key the same.
Ok, I have updated our test. UIStartupTest is passing again (in build N20050523-0010). John, are you happy with the numbers?
Yes, it looks good.

Bug.Summery: (Plat) Documentation for standalone GLA
Bug.WithStack:
The standalone GLA is a new package. It need documentations. According to Dave, there documentation from AC can be reused.

Yes, see https://w3.opensource.ibm.com/web/ac- tech/drops/3.3.0_20050410_2220.html for the AC GLA runtime documentation. We probably can reuse it but just need to strip out the IBM specific stuff. Bug.Summery: [Contributions] PageSite.registerContextMenu does not handle the same menu being registered under different ids
Bug.WithStack:
build N20050506
PageSite.registerContextMenu always creats a new PopupMenuExtender. It should do the lookup to see if a matching extender already exists for the menu manager and selection provider. Changed to delegate to PartSite.registerContextMenu, which has this logic.
Doug, could you please double-check my change?
Interesting. Good catch. Verified in I20050509-2010.

build N20050506

Bug.Summery: All Declarations does not include the namespace scope in the search pattern
Add serialVersionUIDs for classes that implement java.io.Serializable.
Bug.WithStack:
Add serialVersionUIDs for classes that implement java.io.Serializable.
The following scenarios should specify a serialVersionUID:
-Classes that implement java.io.Serializable. -Classes that implement interfaces that extend java.io.Serializable. -Classes that extend other classes that fulfill the above criteria (e.g. extending java.lang.Throwable).
The serialVersionUID is a stream-Unique Identifier (SUID) for Java binary de- serialization of a class. If the serialVersionUID is not specified, the JVM will compute it automatically based on fields and methods in the class. If a compatible change is introduced between releases, the Java binary de- serialization of the class would be broken between releases. The value of the serialVersionUID MUST not be modified unless an incompatible change is introduced.
See the 'Java Object Serialization Specification' for more details.
Compatible changes include: -Adding, modifying access or modifying static/transient to non-static/non- transient of fields. -Adding or removing classes. -Adding or removing writeObject/readObject methods. -Adding java.io.Serializable inheritance.
Incompatible changes include: -Deleting, modifying non-static/non-transient to static/transient or modifying the declared type of fields. -Modifying the hierarchy or interchanging/removing java.io.Serializable/java.io.Externalizable inheritance of the class. -Modifying writeObject/readObject methods. -Adding writeReplace/readResolve methods.
The serialVersionUID can be generated using the <JDK home>/bin/serialver.exe utility. Paul, your request is valid. However, I don't think making changes of this nature to the source code is the build team's responsiblity. Please open bugs to component owners to ask developers to ensure classes that extends Serialization to have serialVersionUID specified. Opened defects for individual components. Closing.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Add serialVersionUIDs for classes that implement java.io.Serializable.
The following scenarios should specify a serialVersionUID:
-Classes that implement java.io.Serializable. -Classes that implement interfaces that extend java.io.Serializable. -Classes that extend other classes that fulfill the above criteria (e.g. extending java.lang.Throwable).
The serialVersionUID is a stream-Unique Identifier (SUID) for Java binary de- serialization of a class. If the serialVersionUID is not specified, the JVM will compute it automatically based on fields and methods in the class. If a compatible change is introduced between releases, the Java binary de- serialization of the class would be broken between releases. The value of the serialVersionUID MUST not be modified unless an incompatible change is introduced.
See the 'Java Object Serialization Specification' for more details.
Compatible changes include: -Adding, modifying access or modifying static/transient to non-static/non- transient of fields. -Adding or removing classes. -Adding or removing writeObject/readObject methods. -Adding java.io.Serializable inheritance.
Incompatible changes include: -Deleting, modifying non-static/non-transient to static/transient or modifying the declared type of fields. -Modifying the hierarchy or interchanging/removing java.io.Serializable/java.io.Externalizable inheritance of the class. -Modifying writeObject/readObject methods. -Adding writeReplace/readResolve methods.
The serialVersionUID can be generated using the <JDK home>/bin/serialver.exe utility. Paul, your request is valid. However, I don't think making changes of this nature to the source code is the build team's responsiblity. Please open bugs to component owners to ask developers to ensure classes that extends Serialization to have serialVersionUID specified. Opened defects for individual components. Closing.

Bug.Summery: [KeyBindings] command-space eaten by Tiger
Bug.WithStack:
In Tiger, command-space maps by default to "open spotlight search". This causes conflicts with our content assist binding. "http://developer.apple.com/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/OSXHIGuidelines/XHIGKeyboardShortcuts/chapter_20_section_1.html"
"Command+Space" is now "Show or hide Spotlight search field. When multiple languages are installed, may rotate through enabled script systems"
I've posted to platform-ui-dev@eclipse.org asking for comments. See also bug 93596 - we have changed the keybinding to Ctrl+Space. This change will be something to get used to for non-Tiger users. Comments are welcome. Sorry. For some reason, I thought it was platform/ui that defined this key binding.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 93596 *** Removing the milestone....

Bug.Summery: [RCP] Deployment with Java Web Start (JWS, JNLP)
Bug.WithStack:
There is a lot of interest from RCP developers who want to deploy their applications with Java WebStart. A tutorial on how to do this would be nice.
See also: http://www.eclipsepowered.org/archives/2005/02/23/deploying-with-jws/#comment-1458 Pascal, do you want to take responsibility for this one?
I'm goint to start directing people with JNLP questions to come here and add their comments for things they'd like to see in the article that they're having a hard time figuring out on their own. Sure. However note that since I will be writing the help section on this topic, an article might no longer be necessary (see bug #85029). We would be interested in using jnlp within a running RCP Application to lazy download mini-ui jar files, which represents one or a view ui-masks only like html but only once until a new version is available.
it is 'easy' to launch the overall rcp core runtime via webstart, but what about using jnlp as a lazy product updater and installer.
the idea is to fully avoid any product installation except a base product.
the rcp core runtime an some additional custom launching code can be installed by traditional software installation processes or maybe also webstart, but in our case we would install a jre and rcp and a browser as a basic requirement.
the installation of the full application (all features and plugins) should be avoided as far as possible, because this would require a lot of time, and within a business application only a part of the overall application is used.
(Posted on eclipse.platform.rcp, 20 June 2005)
First of all, THANK YOU to Pascal for writing the new Java Web Start documentation for Eclipse 3.1RC3. It helps to have all the concepts tied together like this.
However, I do have some constructive feedback for the documentation. Here goes:
In Step 1: * Is "wrappering" the correct word in this context? Would "wrapper" be more concise? * The instructions say: "Create a feature including all the features that are listed in your product definition." Does this refer to just the plug-ins that are unique to our product, or all the dependencies as well? * The instructions say: "Copy in a folder of your feature the startup.jar." Does this mean: "Copy the startup.jar file into your feature's folder"? * When we add the "root=" line to build.properties, should we specify the absolute path, or the relative path? If relative, should the folder just be "." (dot)?
In Step 2: * At the phrase "You need to use keytool", you may wish to add a hyperlink to http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/guide/javaws/developersguide/development. html#signing which provides an excellent overview of how to use keytool. * "File > Export > Features" should be "File > Export > Deployable Features"
In Step 3: * No questions.
In the section "Plug-ins based application" * This section is very confusing to me (maybe it's just me!). I thought _all_ of the instructions thus far were specifically for plugin-based (RCP) applications. Why a separate section for it? Weren't we told to create a wrappering feature in Step 1? Are we supposed to create a second wrappering feature, different from the first? Any additional words of clarification for this section would be very appreciated.
In general: * Every occurrence of the word "than" in the document can be safely replaced with "as".
I hope this helps for RC4 and beyond! Please let me know if you have any questions or want clarification on any of my comments herein posted.
Thanks, Geoff Thanks to all (especially Mr Rapicault) for your work on JWS launching for RCP apps. I followed the documented process and it works very nicely.
However at the moment I still have to deploy my application using a series of clicks in my IDE. I really need to automate this from my ANT build. Has anybody been able to create a build.xml that they can run outside of Eclipse to build all the artifacts for a JNLP deployment? Nothing has been done to this extent. However from experience, I've noticed that the main jnlp file does not change much so you should be able to get a pretty good level of automation. For further discussion, I recommand that you enter a feature request against pde build. Since this seems adequately covered in the 3.1 documentation a seperate article is not necessary. Closing.
FYI here's a link to the doc:
http://help.eclipse.org/help31/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/java_web_start.htm
If there are any problems with the doc please open seperate bugzilla entries on them.

Bug.Summery: padding ignored for directed graph layout
Bug.WithStack: Padding for nodes was ignored in HorizontalPlacement, but not in CompoundHorizontalPlacement. Added support to look at padding. Fixed in HEAD
Bug.WithOutStack: Padding for nodes was ignored in HorizontalPlacement, but not in CompoundHorizontalPlacement. Added support to look at padding. Fixed in HEAD

Bug.Summery: [Forms] Incorrect TAB order in preference pages with swivels
Bug.WithStack:
Look at any preference page containing swivels. The first swivel heading is skipped when focus enters that page's composite. For example, place focus on the "Text Editors" hyperlink in Java Editor prefs page, and press TAB. On OS X the first two are skipped. Additionally, should these things be drawing focus in some way? There is no indication of the focus control when one of these are selected... I do draw focus indication on all the platforms - don't know what is happening on Mac though.
TAB order is a known problem. Probably the wrong colors are being used for FG and BG. The MAC does not support XOR, so GC.drawFocusRect has slightly different behavior. I think it uses either only FG or only BG color.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 79981 ***

There is no indication of the focus control when one of these are selected... I do draw focus indication on all the platforms - don't know what is happening on Mac though.
TAB order is a known problem. Probably the wrong colors are being used for FG and BG. The MAC does not support XOR, so GC.drawFocusRect has slightly different behavior. I think it uses either only FG or only BG color.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 79981 ***

Bug.Summery: [Forms] Focus rect should be drawn around text, not swivel triangle
Bug.WithStack: Label, Checkbox, Button, Toolitem, Hyperlink, Treeitem, etc., all draw focus and/or selection emphasis around the text being displayed, and not the icon/graphical portion of the UI. The swivel control used in the preference pages draws the focus rectangle in a location that is not consistent with anything else in the platform. Fixed in M5
Bug.WithOutStack: Label, Checkbox, Button, Toolitem, Hyperlink, Treeitem, etc., all draw focus and/or selection emphasis around the text being displayed, and not the icon/graphical portion of the UI. The swivel control used in the preference pages draws the focus rectangle in a location that is not consistent with anything else in the platform. Fixed in M5

Bug.Summery: List selection events no longer have an item
[Forms] Preference subsection should be revealed when swivel expanded
Bug.WithStack: When a treeitem is expanded, the tree scrolls such that the maximum amound of children under the parent can be viewed, still showing the parent treeitem. A swivel should do this too. It is frustrating to expand a preference section, and not be able to see anything except the vertical scrollbar appearing, or to see a clipped version of the subsection. Fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack: When a treeitem is expanded, the tree scrolls such that the maximum amound of children under the parent can be viewed, still showing the parent treeitem. A swivel should do this too. It is frustrating to expand a preference section, and not be able to see anything except the vertical scrollbar appearing, or to see a clipped version of the subsection. Fixed.

Bug.Summery: Don't rebuild on close event
Bug.WithStack:
AJDT currently tries to rebuild an out of date project when closing it. This should be disabled...
This wouldn't be a problem normally, although when I have the project open in another Eclipse instance it seems to hang :-( I'm going to close this bug. We can't do anything about when a build is triggered - that's done by the Eclipse infrastructure. We also can't tell whether the project is being closed or not. However we had a separate bug for the build hanging, which was fixed for 1.2.1 and 1.3, so you should now be able to cancel the build.
Bug.WithOutStack:
AJDT currently tries to rebuild an out of date project when closing it. This should be disabled...
This wouldn't be a problem normally, although when I have the project open in another Eclipse instance it seems to hang :-( I'm going to close this bug. We can't do anything about when a build is triggered - that's done by the Eclipse infrastructure. We also can't tell whether the project is being closed or not. However we had a separate bug for the build hanging, which was fixed for 1.2.1 and 1.3, so you should now be able to cancel the build.

Bug.Summery: [Help] HelpView uses 300ms when opening java editor

Lines.Line: - if the view is normally visible/open it's not taking 300ms but still 68ms
(open editor takes about 850ms)
- if the view is a fast view Help does not appear in the trace
- if the view is minimized it uses the same amount of time as if fully visible
- I also see that the minimized view takes the same amout of time as the normal view
- time increases with larger files
- time us used while minimized but not while fast view

Bug.WithStack:
N20050505
When tracing the time spent when opening Java editors (bug 88050), I notices that quite a considerable amount of time is spent reflowing the HelpView. On my P4 2.4Mhz 1GB, the time used by the HelpView is usually a couple hundred milliseconds, accounting to around 1/3 of the total editor opening time.
Not sure whether there is an easy way, but to me it seems that the help view should not spend so much time, especially since it is minimized (not showing).
I will attach a trace. Created attachment 20843 ST.cpu
yourkit trace of opening StyledText.java - reflowing the help view uses 340 ms. Tom, I did a quick check and help did not appear in my trace. I even had Help in front. Created attachment 20863 help_view_on_editor_open.zip
zipped html pages showing the traces.
help_view_on_editor_open.html shows the traces from the PartService.setActivePart call that is fired when any editor is opened.
help_view_reflow.html shows that the entire time spent inside the HelpView.partActivated method (434ms in this case) is burnt by ManagedForm.reflow.
Note that the view is reflowed both on part activate and partdeactivate. Tom, do you still see this problem with RC1+ builds? Tom, I assume you did this after the Help view generated the help index, right? Please trace again, I will do the same WindowsXP. Let's do this today, so that Help has enough time to address if this is still an issue. If it is, I consider this as a major problem which needs to be fixed before shipping 3.1. Reverted my priority change, didn't want to change other component's schedule. Created attachment 22302 Profiler data
Here my findings for WindowsXP opening a very small file after Help view has been opened and waited for the indexer to complete:
Very small file: ---------- public class Other { public static void s() {} } ---------- opened with the CU editor from the Package Explorer: - if the view is normally visible/open it's not taking 300ms but still 68ms (open editor takes about 850ms) - if the view is a fast view Help does not appear in the trace - if the view is minimized it uses the same amount of time as if fully visible - I also see that the minimized view takes the same amout of time as the normal view
- On my system, the help view consumes more time if I open a larger file. Can reproduce the 300ms when opening StyledText.java in the class file editor (not as editable source).
- I also see frequent flashing when reselecting the already selected element in the package explorer with the mouse. It seems that the help view reflows itself upon every received selection event, even if the selection did not change. >I also see frequent flashing when reselecting the already selected element I do not see this under WindowsXP, so maybe that adds up to the penalty of 300ms? Created attachment 22309 Profiler data
Same results under WindowsXP: opening StyledText (imported from N20050603-0010) in the Class File editor via Package explorer takes > 300ms. No idea why this takes longer with a bigger file.
This one did not show up with the small file and also not when opening a very small class file: 1.81% - 200 ms - 2 inv. - org.eclipse.help.ui.internal.views.DynamicHelpPart$4.run() Increasing severity to 'major' because 300ms is quite a big amount of time and it should be investigated why - time increases with larger files - time us used while minimized but not while fast view
The view keeps track of its visibility and ignores input when hidden. Perhaps we didn't check for the minimized state or we cannot get that information from the workbench. Dejan, can this be addressed for 3.3? Given the time we spent to investigate and fix performance issues I think this one should not be downgraded. I'll do a profiel to see if this still exists in Eclipse 3.3. This is no longer a problem.
I just did some profiling using I20070417-0800 and YourKit with CPU sampling enabled. If the help view was open I did see about 300ms spent in the help view when the editor was opened. If the help view was minimized no time was spent there. Can you explain what the view does in this 300ms? Could this be moved in the background (job) as we do e.g. for the Javadoc view where we first compute the new data in a job and if the input indeed changed we set the new input in the UI thread.

Bug.Summery: [quick fix] missing option to raise visibilty of overriding method

Lines.Line: 1) Behavior is inconsistent. If Base.doSomething is public, and
Base.doSomething is protected, the quick fix to raise visibility _is_ offered.
2) The existing quick fix is in error. If Base is in another class file, then
reducing the visibility of Base.doSomething will not resolve the compilation error.

Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] [KeyBindings] Command+W should close dialogs on OS X

Lines.Line: (1) We need to remove the Cmd+W keybinding for Close Tray in the help.

(2) As Susan mentioned in comment#5, we need a public way to set the return value in the Dialog. (I've made the Window.setReturnCode() public in my workspace for this patch to work, but that would break binary compatibility) Susan, adding an API in Dialog is possible?
Updating the dependency with the right bug id :-)

Remy suggested using reflection to avoid introducing a public method. Given the nature of the use case and the fact that handlers already use reflection extensively (see WidgetMethodHandler), I wonder if this is a better choice.

I don't think you need bug 293025. Why don't you just call Shell#close()? That should do exactly what the user gets when she clicks the close button. If the dialog wants to veto the closing, then it should be able to do so.

Bug.WithStack:
Generally any window can be closed using command-W. Our dialogs don't conform to this behaviour... not sure if they should. Paul, do you think this is something we should do? Fixing up the binding for mac would just be nulling out the help M1+W in dialogs (Help - Close Tray) and pointing to a close dialog command.
Implementing a close dialog command that works across our dialogs seems to be complicated, however. Susan, do you have an idea of how to do that?
PW
There is public API to close a window, but the trick is setting the correct window return code. A CANCEL return code is typically what is set when the user closes the shell by clicking on the close box. This would require a public way to set the return code of the window before calling close().
I guess the bigger question is whether this is an important enough issue from a Mac user's perspective. When Kim first opened the bug, the comment was "not sure" if we should conform to this behavior, so I don't know if there's any question as to whether this should be done. cc'ing Andre since he is also a mac user. Yes, being able to close all windows with Command-W is important.
And I don't understand the technical problem since Command-W should do exactly the same as clicking on the windows close button. So could not the handler for Command-W just call the handler that is installed for the window's close button? How is this done on Windows? IIRC some function key (F3?) is equivalent to pressing the windows close button. I can look at this during M2. In the meantime, cc'ing Steve...should command-W "just work" on the Mac from an SWT point of view? I'll just mention that COMMAND+W in a workbench window doesn't close the window, it just closes the active editor.
PW
Removing milestone. We simply ran out of time. As per http://wiki.eclipse.org/Platform_UI/Bug_Triage_Change_2009 *** Bug 117577 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I miss this all the time. For modal dialogs without a close box (e.g. Open File), it's OK to just support Esc for Close, but if the red close button is active in the title bar, then Command+W should work. Created attachment 149908 Patch v01
(1) We need to remove the Cmd+W keybinding for Close Tray in the help.
(2) As Susan mentioned in comment#5, we need a public way to set the return value in the Dialog. (I've made the Window.setReturnCode() public in my workspace for this patch to work, but that would break binary compatibility) Susan, adding an API in Dialog is possible? Updating the dependency with the right bug id :-) Remy suggested using reflection to avoid introducing a public method. Given the nature of the use case and the fact that handlers already use reflection extensively (see WidgetMethodHandler), I wonder if this is a better choice. I don't think you need bug 293025. Why don't you just call Shell#close()? That should do exactly what the user gets when she clicks the close button. If the dialog wants to veto the closing, then it should be able to do so.
And I think the keybinding should only be active for platform="carbon". Created attachment 151671 Patch v02
(In reply to comment #14) > Why don't you just call Shell#close()?
Its because that doesn't set the return code to CANCEL and doesn't do the cleanup in Window/Dialog. hmmm but wait. It looks like Window.handleShellCloseEvent() just does that. So Shell.close() should be fine. Thanks Markus.
> And I think the keybinding should only be active for platform="carbon".
Why do we need this? The fix is on the cocoa fragment. (a similar patch for carbon fragment is needed) > > And I think the keybinding should only be active for platform="carbon". > > Why do we need this? The fix is on the cocoa fragment. (a similar patch for > carbon fragment is needed)
Oh, I missed that the fix is in the fragment, so it's maybe really not needed (assuming that extension points are really not read when a fragment is not loaded). Created attachment 153417 Patch v03
Patch for both carbon and cocoa fragments Patch v03 released to HEAD I don't believe you can just define a keybinding for "M1+W", since I see a binding for Close Tray in dialogs for that sequence. You need to define a cocoa or carbon binding for M1+W in your fragments.
PW (In reply to comment #19) > I don't believe you can just define a keybinding for "M1+W", since I see a > binding for Close Tray in dialogs for that sequence. You need to define a > cocoa or carbon binding for M1+W in your fragments. > > PW
The bug # 294571 is opened for the Close Tray already.
I've defined the bindings in the respective fragments only. Didn't understand what should be done. (In reply to comment #20) > > The bug # 294571 is opened for the Close Tray already. > > I've defined the bindings in the respective fragments only. Didn't understand > what should be done.
If I provide a plugin and include a keybinding in dialogs to M1+W, as soon as you launch on carbon you will get an error, and M1+W will do nothing.
We protect ourselves against this by targetting our keybinding on carbon (since it is carbon specific) which means it will be chosen over a non-platform specific keybinding for M1+W
PW Created attachment 153493 Patch v04
(In reply to comment #21) > We protect ourselves against this by targetting our keybinding on carbon (since > it is carbon specific) which means it will be chosen over a non-platform > specific keybinding for M1+W > > PW
Ok. This would do? (In reply to comment #22) > Ok. This would do?
I think that's all it needs. That will give those bindings priority on carbon and cocoa respectively.
PW Patch v04 released to HEAD Verified in I20091207-1300

Bug.Summery: BundleFile.getFile() to support permissions
Bug.WithStack:
Follow up on bug #88697.
It would be desirable to have BundleFile.getFile() take file permissions, so files can have permissions when extracted. There is a new configuration option "osgi.filepermissions.command" that can be used to set permissions of extracted files.
See bug 126599 comment 4 for more information on the options in 3.2
Bug.WithOutStack:
Follow up on bug #88697.
It would be desirable to have BundleFile.getFile() take file permissions, so files can have permissions when extracted. There is a new configuration option "osgi.filepermissions.command" that can be used to set permissions of extracted files.
See bug 126599 comment 4 for more information on the options in 3.2

Bug.Summery: List selection events no longer have an item
Make ListenerList API

Lines.Line: 1. N Y Y N
2. Y N Y N
3. Y Y Y N
4. Y Y Y N
5. N Y Y N
6. N Y Y N
7. N Y Y N
8. N Y Y N
9. N N Y Y
a. N N Y *

Bug.WithStack:
We should make the runtime ListenerList class API. There are eight copies of this class in the platform, almost none of which have incorporated the various thread-safety fixes that have been added to the class in runtime. I am adding this analysis made by Bob Foster on the platform-ui-dev mailing list:
There are eight (8) classes named ListenerList and one named ListenersList. A quick search found two ad hoc (ArrayList) listener lists. I looked at one of them (a). Their behaviors are described in the table below. Note that (3,4) are alike, as are (1,5-8). Not as DRY as my humor. 2 looks like the most efficient threadsafe implementation when add/remove is much less frequent than events.
The only behavior common among all of them is they all allow modification of the list during an event. So a list that used an iterator would be, excuse the second pun, exceptional.
T C M A 1. N Y Y N 2. Y N Y N 3. Y Y Y N 4. Y Y Y N 5. N Y Y N 6. N Y Y N 7. N Y Y N 8. N Y Y N 9. N N Y Y a. N N Y *
T - Threadsafe C - Copy before firing M - allow Modification during event A - Add/remove affects current event
1 - org.eclipse.update.internal.core.ListenersList 2 - org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.ListenerList 3 - org.eclipse.core.internal.variables.ListenerList 4 - org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.ListenerList 5 - org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.refactoring.ListenerList 6 - org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.ListenerList 7 - org.eclipse.jface.util.ListenerList 8 - org.eclipse.ltk.internal.core.refactoring.ListenerList 9 - org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable a - org.eclipse.jface.util.DelegatingDragAdapter (ArrayList)
5,6 appear to be duplicates * - Remove depends on where in list; also remove current listener during dragStart will cause next listener to be skipped. Consider also clients which must keep track of multiple types of listeners. For example, EventTable in SWT, or EventListenerList in GEF. And, that some types of listeners are rarely used. GEF identifies listners by .class, but we could switch to using ints like SWT.
Using one instance of "ListenerList" per listener type is not a good idea when the types of listeners is large compared to the typical number of listeners.
Another consideration is whether changes made to the listeners need to have an effect on code which is currently iterating over the listeners. SWT requires this behavior. Yes, I am aware that SWT cannot use any solution provided by core. I don't understand the statements in comment 2. ListenerLists are just basic collections that favor usage patterns common in the implementation of event notification mechanisms. They do not make any assumptions about the type of the elements (they don't invoke operations on the elements). For example: void addListener(int type, Object listener); void removeListener(int type, Object listener); Iterator getListenersOfType(int type); It is a different, also common, use case. I would suggest creating a separate TypedListenerList implementation. Created attachment 27229 Proposed implementation
Attached is the proposed ListenerList implementation. I considered releasing this for M2, but realized there is danger of breaking code that is doing package imports of both org.eclipse.core.runtime and org.eclipse.jface.util, so it is better to wait until after M2. Should I open a separate bug for typed listener lists? If you like. Typed listener lists seem to be specialized enough that I'm not sure a runtime level implementation is warranted. We have one in core.resources, ResourceChangeListenerList, but it makes some specific optimizations that may not generalize well. I certainly don't see the same proliferation of duplicate typed listener list implementations that I see of the simple ListenerList. > I certainly don't see the same proliferation of duplicate typed listener list implementations that I see of the simple ListenerList.
That's because the workaround is to create multiple instances of the plain ListenerList. For example, from PackageViewerWrapper:
private ListenerList fListenerList; private ListenerList fSelectionChangedListenerList; private ListenerList fPostSelectionChangedListenerList;
public PackageViewerWrapper() { fListenerList= new ListenerList(); fPostSelectionChangedListenerList= new ListenerList(); fSelectionChangedListenerList= new ListenerList(); }
While the cost of 3 fields might be negligible for a few viewers, it doesn't scale when its 10,000 notifiers with 20 listener types. This change be considered in light of the breakup of the Runtime that we are currently considering. Here's a more familiar example than the one in comment 9 (which is from some deprecated class in JDT)
"Viewer" declares: private ListenerList selectionChangedListeners = new ListenerList(3); private ListenerList helpListeners = new ListenerList(1);
its subclass "StructuredViewer" adds: private ListenerList doubleClickListeners = new ListenerList(1); private ListenerList openListeners = new ListenerList(1); private ListenerList postSelectionChangedListeners = new ListenerList(1);
whose subclass "AbstractTreeViewer" adds: private ListenerList treeListeners = new ListenerList(1);
while "CheckboxTreeViewer" adds a 7th listener: private ListenerList checkStateListeners = new ListenerList(3); I guess this would be the place to document "requirements and behavior" for a ListenerList in general?
I have not looked at all 8 like Bob has :) .. but, from a high level would like to say that I prefer the kind that copy the list on add/remove, not on the sending/notification (most cases I've seen do add/removes much less frequently than sending events) ... I guess ideally, there'd be two, with some "debug performance hooks" that would allow developers to monitor typicially use scenerios to see if right choice was made. Also, I think, copy-on-add-remove behavior does imply a behavior that would have to be well document and adhered to ... listeners can receive nottification after they have removed themselves from the list (rare, but, I've seen it in practice -- should this be a general contract rule? since I'm not sure any less strict rule is ever safe.
Another "requirement" I'd like to propose is one of allowing (?requiring?) the "requester" to name themselves in the add request and, obviously, in the remove request. This allows for better debugging on "who's responsible for not removing this listener". This may sound extreme, but I think there are so many problems and memory leaks caused by code not (correctly) removing listeners that it might be worth is. [The idea being that both for plain breakpoint debugging, and for tools similar to "sleak", hooks could be used to see "who added this listener that should no longer be in memory). [As far as I know, while not required, its a pretty typicial pattern for the object that adds the listner to also be responsible for removing it. ... Let me know if that's just my pattern :) ]
And, don't get me wrong, I am not suggesting neither the reporter nor assignee :) must be the one to implement all this! Just posting this comments here for general long term "listner lists" requirements. The proposed attachment looks fine to me (but, I'd suspect, will not be the end of better mouse traps).
Thanks.
Comments and suggestions are always welcome, but just to be clear, the stated goal of this bug was to "make ListenerList API", not "invent new listener list framework". Since there are at least eight copies of the class in the SDK, I am satisfied that the current list is sufficient for a broad enough group of clients to warrant moving it to API. The fact that most of those copies have not incorporated subsequent thead-safety fixes to the original makes the case even more compelling.
Implementation note: the attached implementation is just the internal runtime ListenerList with javadoc cleanup. It performs copy on write, which means that it will be possible for listeners to receive notification after they are removed. The only way I know of to avoid notification to removed listeners is to synchronize both list modifications and notifications, which I believe is highly deadlock prone because it will lock threads while invoking arbitrary listener code. > We have one in > core.resources, ResourceChangeListenerList, but it makes some specific > optimizations that may not generalize well.
I agree. In this list, every listener is wrapped in an object which tags the events that it is interested in. The alternative would have been to just notify all listeners all the time, and let each listener ignore events based on their type. This avoid the unnecessary wrapper and mask. The only drawback would be that you couldn't add new event types safely.
Another way to use a normal listener list would be to make the filter mechanism API, so that listeners could wrapper a filter around themselves if they wanted. opened bug 109886 for typed lists. I'll defer releasing this because the runtime plugin is undergoing reorganization; I don't want to add the class only to move it soon afterwards. It would be interesting to have a ListenerList in the new common plugin that we are looking at. John, can you point Oleg at the right code? Proposed implementation is attached to comment #6. This is essentially the existing runtime listener list with javadoc cleaned up. The new API class org.eclipse.core.runtime.ListenerList has been released. It is found in the org.eclipse.equinox.common plugin (also exported by the org.eclipse.core.runtime plugin).

Bug.Summery: (MON) shell scripts in GLARuntime.zip do not have execute permission
Bug.WithStack:
Some of the sample shell scripts in GLARuntime.zip do not have execute permission when unzipped on non-Windows machines. Here are the specific script files affected:
GenericLogApapter/config/Apache/access/v1.3.26/runregex.sh GenericLogApapter/config/Apache/error/v1.3.26/runregex.sh GenericLogApapter/config/XML/CommonBaseEvent/v1.0.1/runregex.sh
These files should have 755 permissions.
I found this problem with TPTP 3.3 20050509_0816 build. This should be fixed for 3.3 iteration 3. Bug.WithStack:
The Open Again command that has appeared on our file menu is very confusing. I had NO idea what it did when I used it. I had to ask Doug what it was doing. This could probably be named better... perhaps it could contain the name of the file that would be opened again? It's being renamed and moved to Window > New Editor. Bug.Summery: [implementation] AbstractTextEditor is opening modal dialogs inside an activate listener

Lines.Line: 1. Opening a dialog is part of the specification for the method being
implemented and all of its callers.
2. This is the very last chance to notify the user of an error that is so severe
it will bring down the app.
3. The dialog is being openened inside an SWT event listener or *syncExec
(although the latter is very bad UI design) rather than a method inherited from
some base class or interface. The SWT framework itself is usually prepared to
deal with modal dialogs being opened from pretty much anywhere.

Bug.WithStack:
If a text file is changed on disk while it is open in Eclipse, the text editor will open a modal dialog asking the user if they want to load the changes.
This dialog is opened inside a workbench activation listener, which is a bug because it is not part of the spec for activation listeners to open modal dialogs. (See bug 93700).
The user should be notified using a control that covers the editor, nonmodal shell, on other means that do not run an event loop.
In general, it is only okay to run an event loop if and only if the callers of your method are prepared to deal with the consequences. This occurs if: 1. Opening a dialog is part of the specification for the method being implemented and all of its callers. 2. This is the very last chance to notify the user of an error that is so severe it will bring down the app. 3. The dialog is being openened inside an SWT event listener or *syncExec (although the latter is very bad UI design) rather than a method inherited from some base class or interface. The SWT framework itself is usually prepared to deal with modal dialogs being opened from pretty much anywhere.
Bug.WithOutStack:
If a text file is changed on disk while it is open in Eclipse, the text editor will open a modal dialog asking the user if they want to load the changes.
This dialog is opened inside a workbench activation listener, which is a bug because it is not part of the spec for activation listeners to open modal dialogs. (See bug 93700).
The user should be notified using a control that covers the editor, nonmodal shell, on other means that do not run an event loop.
In general, it is only okay to run an event loop if and only if the callers of your method are prepared to deal with the consequences. This occurs if: 1. Opening a dialog is part of the specification for the method being implemented and all of its callers. 2. This is the very last chance to notify the user of an error that is so severe it will bring down the app. 3. The dialog is being openened inside an SWT event listener or *syncExec (although the latter is very bad UI design) rather than a method inherited from some base class or interface. The SWT framework itself is usually prepared to deal with modal dialogs being opened from pretty much anywhere.

Bug.Summery: more than one native library per JAR?

source_code.code:
/** * Attribute key for a classpath attribute containing to a comma separated * list of shared libraries that should appear on the * -Djava.library.path system property. *

* The value is a list of comma separated strings representing paths. Each * string is used to create an IPath using the constructor * Path(String). A string used to construct a path may contain * IStringVariable's. Variable substitution is performed on each * string before a path is constructed from a string. *

*

* If the resulting IPath is a relative path, it is interpretted * as relative to the workspace location. If the path is absolute, it is * interpretted as an absolute path in the local file system. *

* @since 3.1 * @see org.eclipse.jdt.core.IClasspathAttribute */

Bug.WithStack:
20050509 I assume a request that we soon wil get is to be able to add more than one native library to a classpath entry. The current API for JavaRuntime.CLASSPATH_ATTR_LIBRARY_PATH_ENTRY supports multiple libraries per archive by allowing for more than one attribute with the same key. We believe we should change the API such that we do not use more than one attribute with the same key. JDT does not currerntly verify this restriction, but may want to. Thus, the API spec for CLASSPATH_ATTR_LIBRARY_PATH_ENTRY would need to be changed to this: /** * Attribute key for a classpath attribute containing to a comma separated * list of shared libraries that should appear on the * -Djava.library.path system property. *

* The value is a list of comma separated strings representing paths. Each * string is used to create an IPath using the constructor * Path(String). A string used to construct a path may contain * IStringVariable's. Variable substitution is performed on each * string before a path is constructed from a string. *

*

* If the resulting IPath is a relative path, it is interpretted * as relative to the workspace location. If the path is absolute, it is * interpretted as an absolute path in the local file system. *

* @since 3.1 * @see org.eclipse.jdt.core.IClasspathAttribute */ Comma might not be a good separator as it can occurr in names. '\0' might be a suggestion, but we would have to see how jdt.core handles that. I filed bug 94404 for the specification update in JDT core. Marking as M7 candidate. Jim, we'd like to make this change for M7. It is an API change, but it is new 3.1 API as of 3.1M6, and JUI is the only known consumer of the API (as well as jdt.launching). Please see comment#1 for a description of the change. If you have a good suggestion for the user of a separator for file system paths, please advise. approved for M7. I do not have any good suggestions for file system path separators. Fixed. Modified spec for CLASSPATH_ATTR_LIBRARY_PATH_ENTRY and added two methods to JavaRuntime to encode/decode the attribute's value to/from strings. Updated tests as well. See #newLibraryPathsAttribute(String[]) and #getLibraryPaths(). The JUI needs to catch upto this change. There are no compliation errors, but the feature won't work until the proper encoding of the attribute is used. Please verify, Kevin. Re-opening to consider using "|" as separator. Fixed, using "|" as separator. This means the current JUI still works (but needs to be enhanced to add multipe paths). Please verify, Kevin. (Changes to JavaRuntime). verified

The current API for JavaRuntime.CLASSPATH_ATTR_LIBRARY_PATH_ENTRY supports multiple libraries per archive by allowing for more than one attribute with the same key. Bug.Summery: [Undo] - Action handlers should provide progress monitor for sharing by operation approvers
Bug.WithStack:
If the action handlers provided their progress monitor and runnable context in the uiInfo adaptable, then operation approver clients could use the same progress monitor or runnable context when approving an operation, rather than creating one themselves.
Specifically, this would let the undo/redo action handlers share a progress monitor with AdvancedValidationUserApprover. released to HEAD. Should appear in 20050509 4pm EDT build. Backing out this change. It goes against the spec for ProgressMonitorDialog, which does not support reusing the dialog for runnables. This would be a nice enhancement for the future. See bug #94166. Consider using subtasks in the future? Simply reusing the dialog doesn't help because the operation approver's work is nested inside the running of the action handler. Discussed problem with Tod. Ideally a SubProgressMonitor could be used, but the current implementation provided by the runtime plug-in assumes that the creator of a SubProgressMonitor knows how many ticks in the parent the sub monitor will use. This is not the case. In fact, it's not even clear how many sub monitors would be used (for example, if there were multiple operation approvers each using the monitor for something different). Further, the operation approvers run before the operation is ever given the monitor, so there hasn't even been a total number of ticks established.
The dialog used for this scenario will need to be smarter. I'll update bug #94166 with new info.
Notes for the future: Consider a dialog whose monitor could handle multiple begin task/tick/done sequences, creating a new sub progress monitor each time, so that each client could treat the monitor as if it were brand new.
It would seem we'd still have to guess about the total number of ticks needed...
As per http://wiki.eclipse.org/Platform_UI/Bug_Triage_Change_2009
