Bug.Summery: [Progress] - need progress dialog that opens after given elapsed time
Bug.WithStack:
For 3.1, I implemented TimeTriggeredProgressDialog in org.eclipse.ui.internal.operations. It opens only after the specified time has elapsed. This would be a good general-purpose dialog.
Even better would be if this dialog could be reused to run multiple runnables. Currently users of ProgressMonitorDialog have to create a new dialog every time they run something. It would be nicer if they could create the dialog once and run runnables with it. This feature would also allow the OperationHistoryActionHandlers to share the progress reporting with the undo/redo operation approvers that run during the running of the handler. (See bug #94164) I mentioned in the previous comment that reusing the dialog would allow the action handlers to share the dialog with the operation approvers that run during the running of the action handler.
A problem caused by having to use multiple dialogs is that the dialog attempts to show a busy cursor prior to running the runnable. Once the busy cursor is on, another dialog is created for the operation approver, which also turns on (and then off) the busy cursor. This means the busy cursor doesn't show in some scenarios. (See bug #94410). If this dialog could be used multiple times with different runnables, we could probably address this issue. I originally opened this bug to suggest that JFace provide a progress dialog that opens after a given elapsed time.
Since then, I've run into some issues with nested use of the progress monitor (see bug #94164). Reusing the dialog won't really help, and my problem isn't as general purpose as I've thought.
It seems a more specific progress dialog for my case would be needed. (One whose monitor could handle multiple begin task/tick/done sequences, creating a new sub progress monitor each time, so that clients could treat the monitor as if it were brand new.)
At any rate, this bug remains open to request the generic feature, and to also request that there be protected protocol for creating the progress monitor, so that subclasses could provide custom solutions without the mess of wrappering them.
There are currently no plans to work on this feature as we have busyCursorWhile in the workbench As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
For 3.1, I implemented TimeTriggeredProgressDialog in org.eclipse.ui.internal.operations. It opens only after the specified time has elapsed. This would be a good general-purpose dialog.
Even better would be if this dialog could be reused to run multiple runnables. Currently users of ProgressMonitorDialog have to create a new dialog every time they run something. It would be nicer if they could create the dialog once and run runnables with it. This feature would also allow the OperationHistoryActionHandlers to share the progress reporting with the undo/redo operation approvers that run during the running of the handler. (See bug #94164) I mentioned in the previous comment that reusing the dialog would allow the action handlers to share the dialog with the operation approvers that run during the running of the action handler.
A problem caused by having to use multiple dialogs is that the dialog attempts to show a busy cursor prior to running the runnable. Once the busy cursor is on, another dialog is created for the operation approver, which also turns on (and then off) the busy cursor. This means the busy cursor doesn't show in some scenarios. (See bug #94410). If this dialog could be used multiple times with different runnables, we could probably address this issue. I originally opened this bug to suggest that JFace provide a progress dialog that opens after a given elapsed time.
Since then, I've run into some issues with nested use of the progress monitor (see bug #94164). Reusing the dialog won't really help, and my problem isn't as general purpose as I've thought.
It seems a more specific progress dialog for my case would be needed. (One whose monitor could handle multiple begin task/tick/done sequences, creating a new sub progress monitor each time, so that clients could treat the monitor as if it were brand new.)
At any rate, this bug remains open to request the generic feature, and to also request that there be protected protocol for creating the progress monitor, so that subclasses could provide custom solutions without the mess of wrappering them.
There are currently no plans to work on this feature as we have busyCursorWhile in the workbench As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Can't inline varargs.
Javadoc links in help view don't navigate directly to specific anchors in HTML

Lines.Line: - show the Help view
- click "All Topics" at the bottom
- select "JDT Plug-in Developer Guide->Reference->API Reference-
>org.eclipse.jdt.core"
- select "IAccessRule"
- go to the Field Detail of K_ACCESSIBLE and click its "Constant Field Values"
link
-> it moves to the correct position in the Constant Field Values page

Bug.WithStack:
Using M6 on WinXP, and using default help settings, clicking Javadoc links in the help view cause the correct Javadoc page to be displayed, but the help view won't navigate to the correct anchor point in the Javadoc HTML--the page loads but won't scroll to the correct location in the docs for the particular field/method one has requested Javadocs for...you're left at the top of the page.
However, right-clicking the Javdoc link in the help view and choosing "Open in Help Contents" (as opposed to the default "Open") will open the Javadoc in an external browser which will navigate to the correct location on the correct page.
Right-clicking in the Javadoc page and choosing "Properties" does show a complete URL including the "#methodName(param list)" anchor name...it's just that the internal help view won't scroll to the specified location. Chris, is scrolling to anchors part of the browser widget native behaviour or some code is required? There are issues with anchors not working on content rendered in memory with Browser.setText. Can you confirm the problem is found on content displayed through Browse.setText? Otherwise, for content published through Browser.setUrl, I'm not aware of any limitation - and they should work automatically. I am using 'setURL'. (note that I'm running win2000)
Paul, after doing some quick testing this seems to work for me, so maybe your case is particular? What I do, running with latest eclipse build:
- show the Help view - click "All Topics" at the bottom - select "JDT Plug-in Developer Guide->Reference->API Reference- >org.eclipse.jdt.core" - select "IAccessRule" - go to the Field Detail of K_ACCESSIBLE and click its "Constant Field Values" link -> it moves to the correct position in the Constant Field Values page
Does this work for you? Do you have another scenario that fails?
Yup, I verified Grant's scenario as well - all seems to work fine. Grant, your scenario works as stated. However, using the following snippet as an example, put the cursor on charAt, and hit F1:
"".charAt(0);
The help view opens correctly, and the top choice shown is:
Java help: Javadoc for 'java.lang.String.charAt(int)'
When I click on the charAt(int) Javadoc link, the String class's Javadoc page loads, but never scrolls down to the charAt method description.
Of course, once the page is loaded, the anchor links it contains work fine--it seems like it's just that initial page load when leaving the "native/pretty" Eclipse help page to an "external" page that seems to be effected. I'm at a loss as how to better describe it. The "?noframes=true" at the end of the url given to the Browser seems to be what's making the difference.
I see this same behavioural difference when I do this in a stand-alone IE (ie.- with and without the "?noframes=true").
Yep, that seems correct...Either taking out the noframes param entirely or putting the # at the end of the url where it's supposed to be works fine:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#charAt(int) http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/String.html?noframes=true#charAt(int)
I take it this should be an easy fix then?
Can you try M7? It works fine for me now (we made some changes). I tried a fresh installation of M7 and I still get the same behavior when clicking on the "Javadoc for 'java.lang.String.charAt(int)'" link.
However, if I right-click that link and choose Open in Help Contents, the correct page and location shows up in the main editor area of the workbench.
Using my above example, the default link goes to:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#charAt(int)?noframes=true
but the Open in Help Content command opens:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#charAt(int)
As long as the javadoc links point directly to a specific html file, why not just drop off the "noframes" param, since it's not needed?
If that param needs to appear for whatever reason, it needs to appear before the named anchor:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/String.html?noframes=true#charAt(int) I experienced the same behavior reported by Paul in comment #10 in Eclipse 3 M7 running on Windows 2000. I tried changing the Preferences for Help > Help View Document Open Mode to "Open in Editor Area", and got the same (bad) result. Phew - it took me a while to realize it is not us who are adding this.
JDT team is creating this particular Javadoc link - see JavadocHelpContext:
if (url != null) { IHelpResource javaResource= new JavaUIHelpResource(element, url.toExternalForm() + "?noframes=true" ); //$NON-NLS-1$ helpResources.add(javaResource);
JDT team needs to add 'noframes=true' before the anchor. Martin, any idea/hint ? The feature comes from bug 21586. fixed > 20050523. '?noframes=true' is now inserted before the anchor Verifying... Verified in I20050527-1300. Dirk, please update state to VERIFIED Marking as verified.

Bug.Summery: [WorkbenchParts] (regression) Close and other editor-sensitive actions not enabled if editor opened but not activated

Lines.Line: - change to single-click mode (in the General prefs page)
- close all editors
- from the Navigator, select a file
- the editor for it opens
- File > Close is still disabled

Bug.WithStack:
build N20050409
- change to single-click mode (in the General prefs page) - close all editors - from the Navigator, select a file - the editor for it opens - File > Close is still disabled
I suspect this is because the action is not receiving a partBroughtToTop event, which CloseEditorAction and other ActiveEditorActions expect. Please consider for M7.
This worked in 3.0.x.
Verified that partBroughtToTop was getting fired in 3.0.2, but is not getting fired in the latest builds.
The problem is more severe than just a missing event. The editor is not being activated, either (watch the toolbars). It's not intended to be activated. This is an intentional feature of single-click mode, so that the triggering view doesn't lose focus. It's more of an issue when using keyboard navigation. When in single-click mode, we specify activate=false to openEditor.
So there should be a partBroughtToTop event, but the editor should not be activated and there should be no partActivated event.
We're having an overloaded terminology conflict. I meant activated in the "active editor" sense, not the "active part" sense.
Even though it is not supposed to have keyboard focus, the getActiveEditor pointer should be pointing to it and its action bars should be enabled. Unless the active editor points to the right spot, the close action will still be disabled if the missing event is fixed. Ah, right. It should be the active editor, but not the active part.
Created attachment 21003 fix for this defect
Attaching patch for code inspection. Stefan, unfortunately I won't be able to review this with you until early RC1. It's probably too risky to be putting into M7 this late anyway.
Deferring to RC1 Fixed in head Verified in I20050527-0010

Bug.Summery: Code Assist broken for QT Class headers

Lines.Line: - Install Eclipse 3.0M6 + CDT 3 M6
- Install MinGW to standard location
- Install QT and request integration with MinGW to be done for you in the installer
- Start Eclipse, add the qt include directory to your include path and create
new Standard Make project
- Add builder that calls the qmake program (before make build) - command line
"qmake -project" in the application directory
- Add builder that calls the qmake program (before make build) - command line
"qmake -makefile" in the application directory
- add new C++ file: main.cpp
- include the "qapplication.h" header
- type the following into the body of main():
- after some wait, the class name expands to QApplication
- continue to type this:

Bug.WithStack:
i have tried to develop a QT ( http://www.trolltech.com ) application using CDT 3.0M6 / Windows / QT 3.3.4 ? and I noticed that the source completion didn?t really do much for me (It recognized the classes, but no parameter hints, no constructor hints etc). While I know that the Code Assist is a work-in-progress, it would be interesting to see why Code Assist worked quite solid for me so far, but fails (tried the new and old Code Assist) so bad for the QT headers. It may be related to their special header macros or something.
I wrote this to the mailing list, and Douglas Schaefer added:
I have heard of Qt giving us trouble in the past. It does have some pretty weird macros to make it look like they are adding concepts to the language. I'm surprised it is still a problem since we've made the parser more completed in 3.0, especially with it's handling of macros. This is something we'll look into. Raising a bug in bugzilla with an example of code that is returning bad results in a content assist would be most helpful.
Steps to Repro (Windows XP):
- Install Eclipse 3.0M6 + CDT 3 M6 - Install MinGW to standard location - Install QT and request integration with MinGW to be done for you in the installer
- Start Eclipse, add the qt include directory to your include path and create new Standard Make project - Add builder that calls the qmake program (before make build) - command line "qmake -project" in the application directory - Add builder that calls the qmake program (before make build) - command line "qmake -makefile" in the application directory - add new C++ file: main.cpp - include the "qapplication.h" header - type the following into the body of main():
Qapp <now ctrl-space for content assist>
- after some wait, the class name expands to QApplication - continue to type this:
Qapplication myApp = new QApp <now ctrl-space for content assist>
- Code Assist shows "No completions available", although clearly, qapplication.h defines several Constructors for that class.
Thanks for looking at this! If I can help with anything, let me know.

I had to use managed make and set up my include and library paths to point at the QT files. Without that content assist will not find anything. well, i'll give it a try -- maybe it's fixed now (hopefully, kdevelop drives me nuts ;-)

Bug.Summery: interface behind probekit UI extension point has become internal
Bug.WithStack:
In 4.0 plugin reorganization, I think org.eclipse.hyades.probekit.ui.IProbeCompileActionDelegateFactory has moved to org.eclipse.hyades.probekit.ui.internal. This interface backs an extension on the probekit UI, so it doesn't seem like it should magically become internal.
Extending "probekitCompileAction" means implementing IProbeCompileActionDelegateFactory. And, indeed, we have just such an extension & implementation in our proprietary code.
I can see marking it deprecated if you're hoping to get rid of it in future (though I think this might be a surprise to Allan). But it is already part of probekit's public contract, so it shouldn't become internal. Should it?
Sorry if Platform.UI is the wrong Component for this...I'm not too sure where probekit UI stuff goes. This should be fixed in 4.0 I4, not 4.1, because it's a plug-in restructuring bug that results in Probekit having a broken API. As Kim wrote, the interface in question is implemented by people who extend the "probekitCompileAction" extension point. If we don't fix this in 4.0 then an extender will have to refer to an internal class, which is bad and wrong.
IBM actually has such an extender, so this isn't just an academic exercise. I'm putting this in Version 4.0 with severity "blocker" because it blocks the IBM extension from using only public APIs.
The fix is easy: change the package name of the interface back to org.eclipse.hyades.probekit.ui. There are no TPTP dependencies on this interface name outside the Probekit UI plugin, so this doesn't have far- reaching consequences. Reassigning to myself, to bundle it with other plugin restructuring problems we find (including bug 94861). Fixed in the 4.0 stream. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

There are no TPTP dependencies on this interface name outside the Probekit UI plugin, so this doesn't have far- reaching consequences. Reassigning to myself, to bundle it with other plugin restructuring problems we find (including bug 94861). Fixed in the 4.0 stream. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: F2 Tooltip description contains only full qualified classname
Bug.WithStack: pressing F2 function key opens a window which contains only the full qualified class name of the currently selected text element and no further description. Holding the Shift key while pressing F2 shows the javadoc description for the element in the external webbrowser (Safari), so I guess the configuration of the javadoc path is ok and the problem is the display of the text in the tooltip window. The information for the hovers and F2 is extracted from source. You need to attach source to get it. There are PRs that request extracting the info from Javadoc (please check bugzilla and add yourself to the cc-list if interested).
Bug.WithOutStack: pressing F2 function key opens a window which contains only the full qualified class name of the currently selected text element and no further description. Holding the Shift key while pressing F2 shows the javadoc description for the element in the external webbrowser (Safari), so I guess the configuration of the javadoc path is ok and the problem is the display of the text in the tooltip window. The information for the hovers and F2 is extracted from source. You need to attach source to get it. There are PRs that request extracting the info from Javadoc (please check bugzilla and add yourself to the cc-list if interested).

Bug.Summery: Repositioning code in dynamic help for dialogs trails behind

Lines.Line: 1.) Open the "New" wizard.
2.) Press "Ctrl+F1" to open the dynamic help dialog, and dock it to the right
(position it flush to the right of the wizard).
3.) Drag the wizard to the right or to the left.

Bug.WithStack:
I20050509-1200, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11
It is possible to get the dynamic help dialog to overlap or trail behind a wizard when docked and repositioning the wizard.
1.) Open the "New" wizard. 2.) Press "Ctrl+F1" to open the dynamic help dialog, and dock it to the right (position it flush to the right of the wizard). 3.) Drag the wizard to the right or to the left.
Notice that the dynamic help dialog will no longer be flush with the wizard. Depending on which way you dragged, it will either now be overlapping the wizard or spaced away from the wizard. The speed at which you drag affects the distance, but even moderate speeds can cause this effect. On GTK, we will open the help window on top of the dialog and no tracking will take place.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20050509-1200, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11
It is possible to get the dynamic help dialog to overlap or trail behind a wizard when docked and repositioning the wizard.
1.) Open the "New" wizard. 2.) Press "Ctrl+F1" to open the dynamic help dialog, and dock it to the right (position it flush to the right of the wizard). 3.) Drag the wizard to the right or to the left.
Notice that the dynamic help dialog will no longer be flush with the wizard. Depending on which way you dragged, it will either now be overlapping the wizard or spaced away from the wizard. The speed at which you drag affects the distance, but even moderate speeds can cause this effect. On GTK, we will open the help window on top of the dialog and no tracking will take place.

Bug.Summery: Non-configurable builder should never be disabled.
Bug.WithStack:
In Eclipse 3.1, we added an "isConfigurable" attribute, and the ability to specify what build triggers a builder responds to. One of the secondary goals of this API was to replace the existing ability to "disable" builders from the Builders property page. This can be dangerous because some builders might not be able to handle being disabled (see requirements doc in bug 60803). The idea was that if a builder is configurable, then setting the active triggers to the empty set would effectively disable the builder
Somehow this slipped through the cracks in implementing the UI changes around bug 60803. This should be considered for the next release, allowing the current "hack" of the external tool builder plugin implementing builder disabling to be replaced by the new core-level facility. Deferred to post 3.1 reopening for 3.2 consideration. Currently not planned for 3.2 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
In Eclipse 3.1, we added an "isConfigurable" attribute, and the ability to specify what build triggers a builder responds to. One of the secondary goals of this API was to replace the existing ability to "disable" builders from the Builders property page. This can be dangerous because some builders might not be able to handle being disabled (see requirements doc in bug 60803). The idea was that if a builder is configurable, then setting the active triggers to the empty set would effectively disable the builder
Somehow this slipped through the cracks in implementing the UI changes around bug 60803. This should be considered for the next release, allowing the current "hack" of the external tool builder plugin implementing builder disabling to be replaced by the new core-level facility. Deferred to post 3.1 reopening for 3.2 consideration. Currently not planned for 3.2 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Dynamic help blocks input to wizard
Bug.WithStack:
I20050509-1200, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11
If you open the dynamic help dialog while a wizard is open, you are no longer able to type in the wizard. This happens because the dialog is automatically switched to a modal dialog by the following line in Shell.createHandle:
if ((style & SWT.ON_TOP) == 0) modal |= (parent != null && (parent.style & bits) != 0);
If this hack in SWT is removed, then you cannot click in the dynamic help dialog. Basically, GTK+ does not appear to support (at very first naive glance) typing anywhere but in the modal dialog, and it cannot handle two modal dialogs. The 3.0 solution for context help was to overlay the dialog with a yellow infopop shell. The user would need to dismiss it to continue working. The new help pane offers much more information, but it is less obvious to users that they cannot use the dialog while it is open.
If we need to ship with the line mentioned above, we should at least do something with the parent dialog to indicate that it will not work until the help window is closed. *** Bug 94737 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** can we increase the priority of this, I think it is important for usability of help? Fixed. Help view will open on top of the GTK dialog and no tracking, flipping etc. will occur.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20050509-1200, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11
If you open the dynamic help dialog while a wizard is open, you are no longer able to type in the wizard. This happens because the dialog is automatically switched to a modal dialog by the following line in Shell.createHandle:
if ((style & SWT.ON_TOP) == 0) modal |= (parent != null && (parent.style & bits) != 0);
If this hack in SWT is removed, then you cannot click in the dynamic help dialog. Basically, GTK+ does not appear to support (at very first naive glance) typing anywhere but in the modal dialog, and it cannot handle two modal dialogs. The 3.0 solution for context help was to overlay the dialog with a yellow infopop shell. The user would need to dismiss it to continue working. The new help pane offers much more information, but it is less obvious to users that they cannot use the dialog while it is open.
If we need to ship with the line mentioned above, we should at least do something with the parent dialog to indicate that it will not work until the help window is closed. *** Bug 94737 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** can we increase the priority of this, I think it is important for usability of help? Fixed. Help view will open on top of the GTK dialog and no tracking, flipping etc. will occur.

Bug.Summery: Warning created by checkstyle plug-in don't appear.

Lines.Line: 1) file a bug against the checkstyle guys
2) debug yourself
3) attach the checkstyle plug-in here so that we can debug it

Bug.WithStack:
I have warnings set to appear as squiggles. Checkstyle created a warning that I had a line longer than 100 characters. The squiggles do not appear, but when I inserted a newline inside that line, all of a sudden the squiggles show up on both lines.
None of checkstyle's markers appear in the editor. This is frustrating because you don't see the warnings unless you open the problems view. For some reason, causing the error range to span across a newline causes them to start appearing.
I'm using version: com.atlassw.tools.eclipse.checkstyle_3.1.1 Please open/report a bug against checkstyle. If their investigation results in being an Eclipse SDK bug they will file a bug with more details. Have you ever tried creating warning markers for which the range included the line and its trailing line delimiter? I'm going to guess that this is causing the problem. You can add markers (e.g. bookmarks) that span exactly one line or several lines. Maybe their markers end just between CR LF. If you can provide more details or steps we can track this further. I think your suspicion might be correct. Would it be too difficult to hack up one of the builders, spell checker, or something, to create a marker at say line 30 which starts at the beginning of the line, and terminates in the middle of the delimiter? Adding markers that end between cr lf works. Adding markers that end between cr lf works. Using the latest version of checkstyle, squiggles appear, but they are not on the same line as the icon for the same annotation in the vertical ruler. It seems that the annotation has the wrong offsets but the right line number.
Do annotations contain redundant information? i.e., can they contain an absolute offset, and also a line number which *should* agree with the offset? I assume that the checkstyle plug-in doesn't do anything with annotations but simply creates markers which do not check anything i.e. you can set offset 0, length 0 and line to 100. You have three choices:
1) file a bug against the checkstyle guys 2) debug yourself 3) attach the checkstyle plug-in here so that we can debug it
oh, choice for is to drop it ;-)

Bug.Summery: [IType] C implementation of IType shouldn't need to hold onto the IASTNode
Bug.WithStack:
It's easier to implement things like built-in functions if IASTNodes don't need to be created and stored on ITypes ... and it's also a style thing.
Would also be a better idea if ITypes are created the same way in C as they are in CPP. This has been fixed for a while now.
Bug.WithOutStack:
It's easier to implement things like built-in functions if IASTNodes don't need to be created and stored on ITypes ... and it's also a style thing.
Would also be a better idea if ITypes are created the same way in C as they are in CPP. This has been fixed for a while now.

Bug.Summery: [misc] Double-clicking selects text incorrectly
Bug.WithStack: While editing inline styles like this one: Received Response Try double clicking on "verdana" or "normal" the whole statement will be selected instead of just the word. In other words "font-family:verdana" will be selected instead of "verdana" Another way to say it is that selection from double-clicking doesn't break on colon's or semi-colons in the html editor I would expand this bug to say that double click support is not intuitive; if it is designed to work as double click does in other text-editing environments, that is not the case at the moment. Double click does not start to select until the mouse is released for the second time. In other text editing engines, the text selects on the second mousedown, and then dragging through the text expand the selection, one word at a time. Currently, trying to work this way expands the selection, until the mouse is released for the second time, at which point the selection snaps back to just the first word clicked. This is not intuitive. It should either not expand the selection at all, or else expand it in a fashion in keeping with the double-click-to-select-word nature. I think it'd be safe to have double click always stop on colons and semicolons in attribute values. As for comment #1, I'd suggest you comment and CC yourself to bug 22880 since that is a bug for all text editors, not just html. reassigning to inbox This is still an issue. I think we have (had) some good discussion going on in Bug 151605. We'll try to condense it there. *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 151605 ***

Bug.Summery: (Test) Scrollbars for Hyades editors are not displayed when window is resized
Bug.WithStack:
Create a new hyades test asset... This can be a test, test suite, deployment, artifact, or location. (JUnit Test Suite and RPT tests and schedules also exhibit this behavior.) Other assets probably display the behavior as well, but those were all I checked.
Resize the Eclipse main window, which in turn resizes the editor frame. When the frame becomes small enough, scrollbars should appear. However, the scrollbars never appear and the editor frame content is cropped, with no way to access the other controls. Resolved by rolling back to have manual compute of control sizes in editor forms. This part of the code enables scrolling, but has the problem of disabling layout management and setting the controls to their largest size (see bug 74136). It was commented out when fixing 74136.
Having both scrolling and proper layout should be possible when adopting Eclipse Forms API (see bug 74949). Thus duplicated 74136 to 74949. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: [Help] Back/Forward buttons in help view inconsistent with internal SWT Browser history
Bug.WithStack:
I noticed that the back/forward buttons on multi-button mice has been disabled in the help view, however a user can still right-click and choose Back or Forward.
When this happens though, the back/forward arrow buttons in the help view header can become "out of sync" with the internally hosted browser's history.
For instance, press F1 when in the Package Explorer to view help, and then click Using Package Explorer View, and then Filtering Elements.
Now use the arrow buttons in the help view header to go all the way back and then all the way forward again...so far so good.
Now, from the Filtering Elements page, right click the body of the page and choose Back...keep doing this until Back is greyed out. I go through two iterations of the same two pages appearing. In fact, the more times you go all the way back and then all the way forward with the help view arrow buttons, the more times you can right-click and choose Back.
Once Back is disabled from the context menu, keep clicking the left/back arrow button in the help view header. You'll have to click it more than just two times to get back to the original help page.
This same behavior also appears in M6 on OS X w/Safari.
It seems that whatever history the help view keeps track of, doesn't stay in sync with the history of the internally hosted web browser control.
Any way for the help view to intercept any typical platform specific key strokes such as Alt-left/Alt-right on Windows, or Command-{/Command-} on the Mac and use its existing back/forward functionality? I suppose the context menu would have to be disabled as well. Reproduced in 3.3 RC4. The help window does not exhibit this problem. *** Bug 144634 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.Summery: [5.0] Add support for {@code} and {@literal} javadoc tags
Bug.WithStack:
Add support for the new javadoc tags introduced in J2SE 1.5: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/tooldocs/windows/javadoc.html#javadoctags This can be rather annoying, e.g. the Javadoc of Object#getClass() is rendered like this: "[..] The result is of type Class where X is the erasure of the static type of the expression on which getClass is called."
Correct would be: "[..] The result is of type Class<? extends X> where X is the erasure [..]". Created attachment 46702 Fix
Here's a patch with test.
To conform to the exisiting code, I wrote "@literal" etc. as manifest string, although I would recommend using TagElement.TAG_LITERAL et al. Last nitpicking: there's a typo in subsituteQualification(). ^ insert t Thanks! Released the patch and adaptions according to comment 2 > 20060724.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Add support for the new javadoc tags introduced in J2SE 1.5: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/tooldocs/windows/javadoc.html#javadoctags This can be rather annoying, e.g. the Javadoc of Object#getClass() is rendered like this: "[..] The result is of type Class where X is the erasure of the static type of the expression on which getClass is called."
Correct would be: "[..] The result is of type Class<? extends X> where X is the erasure [..]". Created attachment 46702 Fix
Here's a patch with test.
To conform to the exisiting code, I wrote "@literal" etc. as manifest string, although I would recommend using TagElement.TAG_LITERAL et al. Last nitpicking: there's a typo in subsituteQualification(). ^ insert t Thanks! Released the patch and adaptions according to comment 2 > 20060724.

Bug.Summery: New class dialog should honor selected class as superclass
Bug.WithStack:
When I right-click on a class in the package explorer and then choose "New / Class...", I somehow expect the selected class to be chosen as the superclass of the new class to be created, but it isn't. I'd find that intuitive, but maybe a "New / Subclass..." would be better if a single class was selected.
Anyways it would be nice not having to click "superclass..." when I had already selected the superclass in the package explorer. To have the superclass field populated, make sure that a _type_ element is selected, not the compilation unit element.
We find this is a good compromise as always populating the superclass field isn't helpful as it just leads to extra work to remove it again in most cases.

Bug.Summery: [Min/Max] Maximized empty editor area
Bug.WithStack:
I20050509-1200, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11
This is probably by design, but the result is a little bit goofy. With no editors open, open an editor in one perspective. Maximize the editor. Switch to another perspective. Close the editor; no editors should be open now. Switch back to the first perspective. There is a maximized empty editor area. In this case, shouldn't we minimize the editor area?
If we close the last editor, we unzoom the editor area in the current perspective, but we don't do it any of the other perspectives. See also bug 117836 comment #2.

I20050509-1200, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11

Bug.Summery: [Workbench] Create specifications for what goes on each top-level menu

Lines.Line: - Apply to all editor types
- Affect open editors. All actions are either expected to open a new editor,
affect the open editor, or affect all open editors.
- Includes any OS-specific actions normally found on this menu
- Actions that affect the entire workspace (switch workspace, import, export,
etc) should be moved to the project menu.
- Modify the contents of the active editor.
- Includes any OS-specific actions normally found on this menu
- Find\replace should be moved to the search menu.
- Annotation facilities (add bookmark, etc.) should be on the appropriate view
menu (and are accessable from context menus), and should not be on the main menbar.
- "Smart Insert Mode" is a preference and should not be here.
- "Set Encoding" is a property and should not be here.
- Move between editors and control the selection within the active editor.
(Suggest moving one of these facilities to a new menu).
- Either take no context or take their input from the selection in the active
editor.
- Contains all actions that initiate search-and-replace (and actions that
iterate over search results?).
- Should contain Find/Replace from the edit menu.
- Takes context from the current selection.
- Affect resources from the workospace.
- Either take their context from the currently selected resource or affect all
resources.
- Should contain import, export, and switch workspace.
- Should contain common actions from the IResource context menu like "Show in
Resource history", and "Show Annotation"
- Contains actions that affect the entire app or entire window.
- None of the actions take any context more specific than the active perspective
- The Navigation submenu should be moved to the Navigate menu.
If we do come up with such guidelines we should ensure that they match platform specific guidelines
whenever possible.

Bug.WithStack:
This results from the discussion in bug 90709.
In order to achieve a consistent UI, we should have clear criteria for what actions are allowed on each menu. If every plugin uses its own justifications for placing its actions, the menus will never have any well defined structure.
I propose that we define clear criteria for what the actions on each menu should have in common, and make a pass through the UI to ensure that we follow those criteria to the letter.
The most important thing to define is where the actions on each menu get their context.
------------------------------
In order to provide a baseline for discussion, I will suggest the following criteria:
FILE MENU ACTIONS: - Apply to all editor types - Affect open editors. All actions are either expected to open a new editor, affect the open editor, or affect all open editors. - Includes any OS-specific actions normally found on this menu - Actions that affect the entire workspace (switch workspace, import, export, etc) should be moved to the project menu.
EDIT MENU ACTIONS: - Modify the contents of the active editor. - Includes any OS-specific actions normally found on this menu - Find\replace should be moved to the search menu. - Annotation facilities (add bookmark, etc.) should be on the appropriate view menu (and are accessable from context menus), and should not be on the main menbar. - "Smart Insert Mode" is a preference and should not be here. - "Set Encoding" is a property and should not be here.
NAVIGATE MENU ACTIONS: - Move between editors and control the selection within the active editor. (Suggest moving one of these facilities to a new menu). - Either take no context or take their input from the selection in the active editor.
SEARCH MENU ACTIONS: - Contains all actions that initiate search-and-replace (and actions that iterate over search results?). - Should contain Find/Replace from the edit menu. - Takes context from the current selection.
PROJECT ACTIONS: - Affect resources from the workospace. - Either take their context from the currently selected resource or affect all resources. - Should contain import, export, and switch workspace. - Should contain common actions from the IResource context menu like "Show in Resource history", and "Show Annotation"
WINDOW ACTIONS: - Contains actions that affect the entire app or entire window. - None of the actions take any context more specific than the active perspective - The Navigation submenu should be moved to the Navigate menu. If we do come up with such guidelines we should ensure that they match platform specific guidelines whenever possible.
Punting to MvM to handle. adding Jin, the guidelines guy
Bug.WithOutStack:
This results from the discussion in bug 90709.
In order to achieve a consistent UI, we should have clear criteria for what actions are allowed on each menu. If every plugin uses its own justifications for placing its actions, the menus will never have any well defined structure.
I propose that we define clear criteria for what the actions on each menu should have in common, and make a pass through the UI to ensure that we follow those criteria to the letter.
The most important thing to define is where the actions on each menu get their context.
------------------------------
In order to provide a baseline for discussion, I will suggest the following criteria:
FILE MENU ACTIONS: - Apply to all editor types - Affect open editors. All actions are either expected to open a new editor, affect the open editor, or affect all open editors. - Includes any OS-specific actions normally found on this menu - Actions that affect the entire workspace (switch workspace, import, export, etc) should be moved to the project menu.
EDIT MENU ACTIONS: - Modify the contents of the active editor. - Includes any OS-specific actions normally found on this menu - Find\replace should be moved to the search menu. - Annotation facilities (add bookmark, etc.) should be on the appropriate view menu (and are accessable from context menus), and should not be on the main menbar. - "Smart Insert Mode" is a preference and should not be here. - "Set Encoding" is a property and should not be here.
NAVIGATE MENU ACTIONS: - Move between editors and control the selection within the active editor. (Suggest moving one of these facilities to a new menu). - Either take no context or take their input from the selection in the active editor.
SEARCH MENU ACTIONS: - Contains all actions that initiate search-and-replace (and actions that iterate over search results?). - Should contain Find/Replace from the edit menu. - Takes context from the current selection.
PROJECT ACTIONS: - Affect resources from the workospace. - Either take their context from the currently selected resource or affect all resources. - Should contain import, export, and switch workspace. - Should contain common actions from the IResource context menu like "Show in Resource history", and "Show Annotation"
WINDOW ACTIONS: - Contains actions that affect the entire app or entire window. - None of the actions take any context more specific than the active perspective - The Navigation submenu should be moved to the Navigate menu. If we do come up with such guidelines we should ensure that they match platform specific guidelines whenever possible.
Punting to MvM to handle. adding Jin, the guidelines guy

Bug.Summery: [Forms] org.eclipse.ui.forms.widgets.Hyperlink draws underline of bounds, rather than text bounds
Bug.WithStack: Hyperlink should only draw an underline under the text in the label. Currently it draws an underline for the whole width of the widget. If the widget is streched out by some layout manager, it can have a very long underline under empty text making it look like a divider. Fixed. Note though that it is not recommended for the link to stretch that way, because the entire area is a focus target and if you click on it, focus rectangle will still be very wide.
Bug.WithOutStack: Hyperlink should only draw an underline under the text in the label. Currently it draws an underline for the whole width of the widget. If the widget is streched out by some layout manager, it can have a very long underline under empty text making it look like a divider. Fixed. Note though that it is not recommended for the link to stretch that way, because the entire area is a focus target and if you click on it, focus rectangle will still be very wide.

Bug.Summery: Web Services Explorer does not handle complex type extensions that use types from a different namspace
Bug.WithStack:
Web Services Explorer does not handle complex type extensions that use types from a different namspace. For example:
<xs:complexType name="A"> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="anotherNamspace:B"> <xs:sequence> <xs:element name="child" type="xs:string"/> </xs:sequence> </xs:extension> </xs:complexContent> </xs:complexType>
where type A and B are from different namspaces fixed and released. Created attachment 20855 Apply this patch to the Explorer plugin verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Web Services Explorer does not handle complex type extensions that use types from a different namspace. For example:

where type A and B are from different namspaces fixed and released. Created attachment 20855 Apply this patch to the Explorer plugin verified.

Bug.Summery: Enable capabilities not checking NATURES_ARE_TRIGGER_POINTS
Bug.WithStack:
Starting from eclipse 3.0.2, there is a setting we can set to determine if the project natures are the trigger points. I'm trying to get this working in WebSphere Integration Developer.
The project I'm creating has a Java nature. If I set the flag NATURES_ARE_TRIGGER_POINTS to be false in the customization ini file, it will not enable the java capability when the project is created. It does work for me when I first create the project from a fresh workspace. But then, when I exit the workspace (with my project created) and restart again, the Java capability will be enabled again.
Since this does not happen on plain eclipse environment, therefore, I put a breakpoint to see where are the capabilities being enabled. Looks like somewhere in WTP is enabling them.
Here is the stack obtained on a breakpoint when restarting the workbench: WorkbenchActivitySupport.setEnabledActivityIds(Set) line:230 WTPActivityBridgeHelperImpl.setEnabledActivityIds(Set) line:54 WTPActivityBridge.setEnabledActivityIds(Set) line:61 TacitMigrationEngine.enabledActivities(IProject[]) line:161 TacitMigrationOperation.execute(IProgressMonitor) line:63 TacitMigrationOperation(WTPOperation).doRun(IProgressMonitor) line:242 WTPOperation$1.run(IProgressMonitor) line:168 Workspace.run(IWorkspaceRunnable,ISchedulingRule, int, IProgressMonitor) line:1673 TacitMigrationOperation(WTPOperation).run(IProgressMonitor) line:188 WTPOperationJobAdapter.run(IProgressMonitor) line:34 Worker.run() line:66 Neeraj, Vijay said I should assign this to you. RATLC01085819 has been opened to make sure the fix will be available for RAD 6.0.0.1 ifix003. The migration plugin has beeen removed from WTP now. Closing already verified defects
